item.title: A Question of Identity: Why Does Scotland Want Independence? It’s Culture vs. Economics
item.description: The debate over Scottish independence sheds an interesting light on the nature of the state, and what citizens expect from their nation.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL IRWIN
item.media:description: Alex Salmond, Scotland's first minister (front center, with large sign) and other supporters of independence in Edinburgh on Tuesday.

item.title: China Asks U.S. to End Close-Up Aerial and Naval Surveillance
item.description: A senior Chinese military official made the request in a meeting with Susan E. Rice, the national security adviser.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: The Times’s Baghdad Bureau Chief Answers Questions on Iraq
item.description: Tim Arango answered questions on Reddit about what it’s like to report from Iraq for The New York Times.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Letter From India: Families Feud Over Delhi Estates
item.description: The first-time author Ratna Vira has stirred up a buzz in New Delhi with "Daughter by Court Order," about a woman cut out of a prominent family's inheritance.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Enrico Fabian for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exclusive property in central New Delhi.

item.title: Ebola Cases Reported Up Sharply in Liberia
item.description: The World Health Organization said the number of new patients in Liberia pointed to “a large but previously invisible caseload.”
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A burial team in Monrovia, Liberia, on Saturday collected the body of a man believed to have died from Ebola. Their workload has grown quickly in recent weeks.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: For Australia, a Celebration of China in Theme Park Form
item.description: Developers are planning a $500 million, 39-acre Chinese culture theme park north of Sydney, Australia.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: Scale of Flooding Stymies Relief Efforts in India and Pakistan
item.description: Perhaps one of the most damaging developments to the relief effort has been the collapse of communication systems.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: An Indian Air Force helicopter took part in relief and evacuation efforts in Srinagar on Tuesday.

item.title: Thousands of Migrants Forced to Leave Israel, Rights Group Says
item.description: Human Rights Watch said the immigrants, primarily from Sudan and Eritrea, had been obliged to return home even though they were at risk of imprisonment or persecution.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: African asylum seekers at a protest in the Negev desert in southern Israel in June.

item.title: Before Pearl Harbor, Japan’s Emperor Cautioned Against War With U.S., Documents Show
item.description: Before Japan’s surprise attack in 1941, Emperor Hirohito said going to war with the United States was “self-destructive,” an official history of his reign said.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Karzai Calls for Afghan Unity, but Ceremony Ends in Discord
item.description: President Hamid Karzai pleaded Tuesday for a speedy settlement to Afghanistan’s political crisis, but the event at which he spoke was marred by hooting and catcalls.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Editorial: Dengue Fever Hits Japan
item.description: The outbreak is another sign of the health impacts of a warming climate.
item.dc:creator: By THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Mexico’s Dubious Reforms
item.description: From education to the oil sector, the government has pledged sweeping reforms. So why is no one celebrating?
item.dc:creator: By ENRIQUE KRAUZE

item.title: Malaysian Jet Over Ukraine Was Downed by ‘High-Energy Objects,’ Dutch Investigators Say
item.description: A preliminary report released on Tuesday supports theories that the plane was brought down over a contested part of Ukraine in July by a missile fired from the east.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: Australian, Malaysian and Dutch investigators examined wreckage from Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 on Aug. 5th near the village of Rozsypne in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese State Broadcaster Gets Its American Rices Confused
item.description: China Central Television used images of Condoleezza Rice in a report about a Beijing visit by Susan E. Rice, President Obama’s national security adviser.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ng Han Guan
item.media:description: Susan Rice with China's state councilor, Yang Jiechi, in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Lens Blog: A Witness to AIDS in South Africa
item.description: Joao Silva has watched South Africa’s response to the H.I.V./AIDS pandemic go from denial to ensuring those afflicted by the virus get the treatment and medications they need.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By JOAO SILVA
item.media:description: A female patient in her bed at the Sparrow Ministries' Rainbow Village. Dec. 20, 2002.

item.title: Trial of Chinese Human Rights Campaigner Is to Begin
item.description: Yang Maodong, better known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, has long been at the forefront of contentious causes in southern China.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Google Is Target of European Backlash on U.S. Tech Dominance
item.description: Regulators want Google to change its algorithm. If Google doesn’t comply, the settlement it reached with Europe this year may be voided and it will face antitrust charges.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: Google’s Street View service surveying Amsterdam; some European countries have fined it.

item.title: The Times’s Baghdad Bureau Chief Answers Questions on Iraq
item.description: Tim Arango answered questions on Reddit about what it’s like to report from Iraq for The New York Times.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Obama Hosts Foreign Policy Experts, Laying Groundwork for Speech on ISIS
item.description: The president invited opinion makers to a dinner, where he spoke about his plans for confronting the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Rebels Kill at Least 12 in Attack on Convoy
item.description: At least 12 people were killed and more than 27 were wounded when suicide bombers attacked a convoy carrying African Union troops and Somali officials, officials and witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMED IBRAHIM

item.title: World Briefing: Chile: Bombing in Santiago Wounds at Least 14 People
item.description: A bomb exploded in a subway station in Santiago, the capital, on Monday, wounding at least 14 people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Peru: 4 Opponents of Illegal Logging Are Found Dead
item.description: An outspoken Peruvian opponent of illegal logging and three other native Asháninka community leaders were brutally slain in a remote region bordering Brazil, tribal authorities said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: As Sweden Nears Vote, Center-Right Is Trailing
item.description: Sweden is now sharply divided over big, emotive issues like immigration and the future of the welfare state.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CROUCH
item.media:description: The Swedish flag in front of a house southwest of Stockholm. The country has maintained an open-door policy to refugees for decades, but has struggled to integrate many of the new arrivals.

item.title: White House Memo: A President Whose Assurances Have Come Back to Haunt Him
item.description: President Obama has been undermined by his own statements, like the one where he said Iraq was “sovereign, stable and self-reliant” with “a representative government.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: U.S. Delegation Is to Visit Moscow to Review Claims of a Missile Violation
item.description: United States officials believe Russia may have tested a ground-launched cruise missile in violation of the 1987 Soviet-American treaty.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Mikhail Klimentyev/RIA Novosti, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center, visiting a youth camp, said, “I want to remind you that Russia is one of the most powerful nuclear nations.”
